Detailed Description

The FreeWill+ Device.

To get more information view the following topics:

Definition at line 639 of file common.idl.

Public Member Functions

Object Repository
Object Repository is a subsystem that allows to create new FreeWill+ objects.

These functions are used to create FreeWill+ objects:

  • in most cases it is enough to provide the Noun (class name) to create an object: use IFWDevice::CreateObject
  • if you need to provide the Noun, the Verb and/or the Parameters, use IFWDevice::CreateObjectEx
  • for full control, use IFWDevice::CreateContext
  • to get IFWUnknown pointers and call QueryInterface on your own, call IFWDevice::CreateUnknown or IFWDevice::CreateUnknownEx

See Creating the FreeWill+ Objects (and following sections) for details.

HRESULT CreateObject (FWSTRING theNoun, REFIID iid,[out, retval, iid_is(iid)] IFWUnknown **)
 Create the default object using a Noun.

HRESULT CreateObjectEx (FWSTRING theNoun, FWSTRING theVerb, FWULONG nParams,[size_is(nParams)] FWPARAM *pParams, REFIID iid,[out, retval, iid_is(iid)] IFWUnknown **)
 Create an object using a Noun, Verb and Parameters.

HRESULT CreateUnknown (FWSTRING theNoun,[out, retval] IFWUnknown **)
 Create the default object using a Noun; returns a pointer to IFWUnknown.

HRESULT CreateUnknownEx (FWSTRING theNoun, FWSTRING theVerb, FWULONG nParams,[size_is(nParams)] FWPARAM *pParams,[out, retval] IFWUnknown **)
 Create an object using a Noun, Verb and Parameters; returns a pointer to IFWUnknown.

HRESULT CreateContext (FWSTRING theNoun, FWULONG idNoun, FWSTRING theVerb, FWULONG idVerb, FWULONG nParams,[size_is(nParams)] FWPARAM *pParams,[out, retval] IFWCreateContext **)
 Similar to IFWDevice::CreateObjectEx but an IFWCreateContext instance is created instead of the actual object.

FreeWill+ Device Configuration
Device configuration is a hierarchical structure with a list of Nouns on the top, their responsive Verbs in the middle and a set of Classes for each verb at the bottom.

The following functions allow to browse, analyse and build-up this structure and thus fine-tune the system repository

See also:
IFWDevice Object as the System Repository

 Adds a new Class name; uses a class instance instead of Clsid; returns its numerical id; notice that classes added with this function will not be stored with IFWDevice::Store function.

Object Registration and Tracking
See Object Registration and Tracking

HRESULT RegisterObject (IFWUnknown *)
 Registers system object - called automatically by creation functions and IFWUnknown::Clone; use this function if you create objects directly (for example using CoCreateInstance or C++ new operator).

HRESULT UnregisterObject (IFWUnknown *)
 Unregisters system object - to be called from inside destructors only!

HRESULT GetRegisteredObjectsCount ([out, retval] FWULONG *)
 Returns the counter of registered objects; may be used to track if all objects have been released when system terminates.

Error Handling
See Error Handling

HRESULT GetStatus ()
 Returns S_OK if no severe error occured or E_FAIL otherwise; any call to GetLastError clears status to S_OK.

Member Function Documentation

HRESULT IFWDevice::GetLastError (  [out, retval] struct FWERROR **   ) 
 

Provides the detailed information on the most recent error (details).

Supplies the full information on the last error. This function clears also the system status so the next call to GetStatus will return S_OK, and also resets some counters provided by GetErrorNum.

Returns:
The last error code, or S_OK if no error occured.

HRESULT IFWDevice::GetErrorNum (  BOOL  bSevereErrorsOnly,
BOOL  bRecentErrorsOnly,
[out, retval] FWULONG * 
) 
 

Returns the counter of error messages, see details for possible options.

This function gives a choice between four distinct counters:

Parameters:
bSevereErrorsOnly If TRUE, only severe errors will be counted. Otherwise both errors and warnings are counted.
bRecentErrorsOnly If TRUE only errors since GetLastError function call are counted. All errors otherwise.

HRESULT IFWDevice::SetUserErrorHandler (  HRESULT(*  )(struct FWERROR *, BOOL bRaised)  ) 
 

Sets the User Error Handler function; see details.

The function passed as a param will be called each time an error is raised (RaiseError) or recovered (Recover). The function of the form:
HRESULT __stdcall Fun(struct FWERROR *p, BOOL bRaised);
will get the last error info and a bool flag detrmining if the error has been raised or recovered. The result of the function will be returned by IFWill::RaiseError, so in most cases you should return p->nCode, unless you want to override the default value.

See also:
Early Warning Systems: User Handlers and Exception Handling

HRESULT IFWDevice::RaiseError (  IFWUnknown *  pSender,
FWULONG  nCode,
FWULONG  nParams,
[size_is(nParams)] FWULONG *  pParams,
FWSTRING  pMessage,
FWULONG  nSeverity
) 
 

Submits and processes the error information (details).

This function is routinely called from IFWUnknown::Error convenience function, with pSender param set to the calling object (see there for details). It processes the error and produces the information available then from GetLastError function.

HRESULT IFWDevice::Recover (  FWULONG  nSeverity  ) 
 

Recovers after an error - see details.

Call this function to change the severity of the last occured error. Usually you will do this to decrease the error severity when the system recovered after a critical error. You can use a special value Recover(FW_SEV_NOTHING) to eradicate any information on this error, or Recover(FW_SEV_WARNING) to leave it as a warning. You are also allowed to increase the severity if required.

HRESULT IFWDevice::PutSevereErrorLevel (  FWULONG  nSeverity  ) 
 

Returns the system current error severity level, see details.

This function defines the system behaviour in case of errors with various severity (FW_SEVERITY) codes. Use one of the following value:

  • PutSevereErrorLevel(FW_SEV_CRITICAL): all but critical errors will be considered just as warnings, in this mode possibly serious errors (FW_SEV_SERIOUS) allow the animation to continue undisturbed
  • PutSevereErrorLevel(FW_SEV_SERIOUS): default setting, critical and serious errors will stop the action
  • PutSevereErrorLevel(FW_SEV_RECOVERABLE): also minor, usually recoverable errors will be treated as critical
  • PutSevereErrorLevel(FW_SEV_WARNING): all messages, including warnings, treated as critical errors
  • any other value will cause FW_E_INVALIDARG error.
